MEMORANDUM
June 12, 1958
To: NAEB Board of; Directors
Jack McBride
Haskell Boyter

Harry J. Skornia
Harold Hill
Cecil Bidlack
Leonard Marks
From: Burton Paulu
Most of you know of my longstanding interest in foreign
and international broadcasting. My graduate work at the
University of Minnesota was mainly in international relations.
During the early years of World War II, I began to follow
news reports from Britain, Germany and Italy on my short wave
radio, A year-and~a-half overseas with the radio section of
the Office of War Information in 1944 and 1945 Introduced me
first-hand to European broadcasting, both domestic and inter¬
national, and later led to the decision to write my doctoral
dissertation about the Voice of America, Then came my
Fulbright year In London (1953-1954), during which I gathered
data for the book on British broadcasting which some of you
have seen, (Incidentally, I finished reading page proof on
it the very week I was elected NAEB president in Atlanta!)
Ever since the book was published, I have wanted to go
back to England to make a study of the effects of competition
on British broadcasting, as well as to look again at radio and
television on the European continent. Unquestionably, the
United Kingdom now provides a wonderful laboratory In which
to see just what happens when a noncommercial benevolent
monopoly like the BBC is joined by an aggressive, commercially-
supported private television system like the ITA, The outcome
of such a contest is of interest to us in this country, too,
since we ascribe so many of the strengths and weaknesses of
our broadcasting system to its competitive commercial status.
We say that our programs are made "good* by competition,
and that they can be good because our commercial system
provides the funds for the best talent. Others complain that
competition forces down program standards, and that ratings
rather than intrinsic merit determine program format.
